transcript:
Patient: The agenda looks good to me. I'm ready to get started.

Therapist: Great, let's begin by reviewing your Positive Data Log. Can you share some of the entries you made since our last session?

Patient: Sure. One thing I wrote down was that I received positive feedback from a client on a project I completed. They said my work was thorough and innovative, which felt good to hear. Another entry was about a conversation I had with a friend who was going through a tough time. I felt like I was able to offer some helpful advice and support, which made me feel competent and valued in that moment.

Therapist: Those are excellent examples of evidence that challenges your negative core belief and supports your alternative core belief. Let's take a moment to really soak in the significance of these experiences. How did it feel to receive that positive feedback from your client?

Patient: It felt really validating and affirming. I guess it showed me that I am capable of producing high-quality work, even if I don't always believe it myself.

Therapist: Absolutely. And what about the conversation with your friend? What did that experience tell you about yourself?

Patient: It reminded me that I have something valuable to offer in my relationships, and that I can be a good friend and support system for others.

Therapist: That's a powerful insight. These experiences provide concrete evidence that you are competent and worthy, contrary to your negative core belief. As we continue to gather more evidence like this, it will become increasingly difficult to hold onto that old belief.

Patient: I can see that. It's just hard to remember these positive experiences when I'm feeling down or doubting myself.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, and it's why we're working on making these techniques a more consistent part of your daily routine. Speaking of which, let's explore the challenges you've been facing with practicing the relaxation and grounding techniques. You mentioned that you often feel too busy or overwhelmed to take breaks when your reminders go off. Can you tell me more about what's going through your mind in those moments?

Patient: I guess I get caught up in this belief that I have to be productive all the time, and that taking breaks is a waste of time. I worry that if I'm not constantly working, I'll fall behind or miss out on opportunities.

Therapist: It sounds like there might be some all-or-nothing thinking going on there, as well as some fortune-telling. These are common cognitive distortions that can contribute to feelings of anxiety and overwhelm. Let's try to challenge these thoughts using some Socratic questioning. First, is it really true that taking breaks is a waste of time? What does the evidence say?

Patient: Well, I know from experience that when I do take breaks, I often come back to my work feeling more refreshed and focused. So logically, I know that breaks can actually improve productivity in the long run.

Therapist: That's a great point. And what about the belief that you have to be productive all the time? Is that a realistic or sustainable expectation to hold yourself to?

Patient: No, I guess not. Everyone needs time to rest and recharge. It's just hard to give myself permission to do that sometimes.

Therapist: I understand. It can be difficult to break out of that mindset, especially if it's been a long-standing pattern. That's why we're practicing these techniques - to help you build new, more balanced habits and beliefs. What do you think about trying to reframe the way you think about breaks? Instead of seeing them as a waste of time, could you try to view them as an investment in your overall productivity and well-being?

Patient: That's a good way to look at it. I like the idea of investing in myself and my well-being, rather than just trying to push through and be productive all the time.

Therapist: Great! Let's continue to explore this idea and see if we can come up with some specific strategies for making relaxation and grounding techniques a more consistent part of your routine.
